User Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; MS-RTC LM 8; InfoPath.2; .NET CLR 1.1.4322)

Steps to reproduce:

Proposal to add the following feature to Firefox:

Firefox shall keep a history of previously "visited" certification-paths (CP) for a given website. For example, if I visited https://bugzilla.mozilla.org then the "Equifax Secure Certificate Authority" followed by the "*.mozilla.org" certificates would be in the CP history for that site.

Upon a new visit to a previously visited site (even if normal history (e.g. cookies, cached pages, etc., were purged; and unless the CP history was purged) if the CP history for the previously visited site has no CP which matches the current visit certificate chain being offered to the browser, then the security indication in the URL bar shall indicate that the user should inspect it. A configuration option (setting) shall also allow the user to specify that in such cases a pop-up question will be given to him/her before actual content from the site will be fetched.

Of-course, due to privacy concerns (which sites did I visit last?) the CP history purge should allow also to remove specific sites and/or CP entries for sites.

Benefits:
1. Users will be more aware of when a certificate chain has changed for a site. For sites like those of banks or those users consider private, this will help users detect any MITM attack which uses a different root CA for a given site.

2. A security "edge" over competing browsers. A "+" for tech-savvy (and therefore also their friends) and market influencers.


Actual results:

N/A


Expected results:

N/A
